bibl.title: Letter from R. Elwood Logan to Philip Showalter Hench, September 9, 1940

div1.p: Logan sends Peabody's pamphlet and describes the loan policy for the slides that accompany it. He refers Hench to Peabody and gives his address.

div1.head: Letter from R. Elwood Logan to Philip Showalter Hench, September 9, 1940
div1.opener:
IN RE
CABLE ADDRESS “LOGY NEW YORK”
DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION
CHARLES RUSSELL, PH.D., CURATOR
GRACE FISHER RAMSEY, PH.D., ASSOCIATE CURATOR
WILLIAM H. CARR, ASSISTANT CURATOR (OUTDOOR EDUCATION)
JOHN R. SAUNDERS, B.A., ASSISTANT CURATOR
HERMAN A. SIEVERS, STAFF ASSISTANT
FARIDA A. WILEY, STAFF ASSISTANT
WILLIAM LORD SMITH, M.D., STAFF ASSISTANT
GEORGINE MARTIN, STAFF ASSISTANT
HAZEL L. MULLER, B.A., STAFF ASSISTANT
THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY
CENTRAL PARK WEST AT 79TH STREET
NEW YORK. N. Y.
September 9, 1940
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of August 26th, I am sending you
under separate cover the pamphlet “The Conquest of Yellow Fever”.
This manuscript accompanies a set of lantern slides which we
circulate at a charge of fifty cents for twenty-five slides and
two cents for each additional slide. The set contains twenty-
five lantern slides. These slides are lent for two day's use.
The borrower is also to pay the transportation charges.

In regard to the article “The Republic Remembers”, I am
referring your letter directly to Dr. Peabody, 152 Harvard Street,
Newtonville, Massachusetts.

I trust that this pamphlet will be of some assistance to you.
Will you kindly return the pamphlet to us when you are finished
using it? Thank you.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, R. Elwood Logan
In charge of
Slide Division REL:DML
